reviewText: Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer (MGM) presents "DEVIL'S DOORWAY" (1950) (84 min/B&W;) (Fully Restored/Dolby Digitally Remastered) -- Starring Robert Taylor, Louis Calhern, Paula Raymond, Marshall Thompson & Edgar BuchananDirected by Anthony MannLance Poole (RobertTaylor cast against type) is a Native American who returns to his people's land after the Civil War and discovers that they are being victimized and persecuted - thanks to machinations of crooked lawyer Verne Coolan (Louis Calhern). Unable to turn to the Law to protect his tribesmen, Lance becomes what white men call a "renegade."The cinematography is nothing short of spectacular, sometimes even haunting; certain outdoor scenes are as memorable as masterpiece landscape paintings (and we're talking black & white here!) -- something to behold.Devil's Doorway was the vanguard of a new western cycle of the early 1950s, wherein the Native Americans were the good guys and the white man the villains. Anthony Mann was at his best on westerns with a dark side and here he shows us the talent that would be responsible for so many great films that were yet to come.BIOS:1. Anthony Mann [aka: Emil Anton Bundesmann] - [Director]Date of Birth: 30 June 1906 - San Diego, CaliforniaDate of Death: 29 April 1967 - Berlin, Germany2. Robert Taylor [aka: Spangler Arlington Brugh]Date of Birth: 5 August 1911 - Filley, NebraskaDate of Death: 8 June 1969 - Santa Monica, CaliforniaMr. Jim's Ratings:Quality of Picture & Sound: 5 StarsPerformance: 5 StarsStory & Screenplay: 5 StarsOverall: 5 Stars [Original Music, Cinematography & Film Editing]Total Time: 84 min on DVD ~ Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer ~ (09/14/2010)

reviewText: Broken Lance (Robert Taylor), a Shoshone who served in the Union Army in the Civil War and was awarded the Congressional Medal of Honor, returns home to Wyoming to take over the ranch owned by his ailing father (Fritz Leiber). He's full of optimism that things will turn out right despite his race, but his father, and his old friend Zeke (Edgar Buchanan), now the new Marshal of the area, foresee trouble, and sure enough it arrives soon enough as the Homestead Act is signed, allowing settlers to take Broken Lance's land, for which he has no title - and not allowing him as a "ward of the government" the same privilege. He tries to fight the system with the help of young lawyer Orrie Masters (Paula Raymond), but violent confrontation seems inevitable...The third of Anthony Mann's three black-and-white westerns of 1950, and in my mind the best of them, DEVIL'S DOORWAY is perhaps the most blatantly pro-Indian western of the decade, and a searing indictment of both racism and our willingness to accept unjust laws, and turn a blind eye towards real justice. It's a fairly blunt film on the whole, without a whole lot of ambiguity in it's rage against the way Broken Lance and his people are treated, but it never feels heavy handed, thanks to many fine little touches in Guy Trosper's screenplay, like the moment when Broken Lance first meets his lawyer and is clearly prejudiced against her sex, leaving her house only to think better of it in a moment outside, coming back abashed and leaving his manly ego behind. And although the principal native roles are played by whites, the custom at the time, there's never a feeling of condescension, and all of the actors seem very committed to this very serious film.The major characteristic that sets Mann apart from his two greatest contemporaries among western directors, Howard Hawks and John Ford, is probably tone - Mann is often unremittingly serious, even bleak, and there are occasionally times in his ouevre when you want a little break from the gloom. But though there are a few very brief lighter moments here, often courtesy of Edgar Buchanan - playing a role that doesn't call out for laughs, for once, but offering a bit of his trademark joviality in a toned-down manner - this is a story that really calls out for Mann's trademark determinism. Apart from Mann, probably only Fritz Lang could have done a film like this at this time, and it's hard to imagine Lang doing it any better.The cast is exemplary, though here more than in most westerns it's the landscape and the big theme that really matter, and there's no question that the characters are in large part archetypes, much as in Mann's previous film The Furies or his later Man of the West. This isn't the story of Broken Lance, or not just the story of Broken Lance, but of all the Indians, and by extension of the African-Americans who Broken Lance helped to free in the war, and of women like Orrie Masters, trying to make it in a "man's" world. It's to the credit of all involved that these big themes rarely seem laid on too thick, and even the several small philosophical declamations made by Broken Lance and others register as poetic rather than grandstanding or hitting the audience over the head.The production values are excellent, and cinematographer John Alton's work is as beautiful as ever, offering a monochrome beauty closer to Ansel Adams than anything else; his daylight scenes are every bit as impressive in their clarity as the dark bar scenes in the early part of the film (which include a truly wonderful bar fight). The Indians' feeling for the land, and their unwillingness to foresake it for reasons that they finally understand - but can't accept or believe - comes across both in Taylor's completely unsentimental performance and in the stark beauty of the whole setting, a gorgeous valley that really does seem like heaven after the brutality and darkness of the town's ornery tavern.  And no western I can think of from this era portrays violence as effectively and harshly as this one; the battle scenes here are just tremendous, brutal and stark in their realism.I could go on and on about this, it was just incredibly impressive to me. At the moment I'd say it joins Man of the West as my favorite of Mann's films, and it's probably the best western of the early 50s. I really hope this new Warner Archive disc helps this film achieve the popularity it deserves.DVD NOTE: As mentioned, this is a no-frills Warner Archive disc.  While I would like to think that this masterpiece might some day get a deluxe Criterion issue with loads of extras, let's face it that's not going to happen, and this disc captures Alton's typically intense lighting just fine.  Extras would be nice, but the film speaks for itself.
summary: The greatest pro-Indian western of it's era

reviewText: "Where are the rest of you?""We're all gone."Only available in the US in a manufactured on demand DVD-R, Devil's Doorway is easily the least seen of all of Anthony Mann's Westerns - not surprisingly, since it's also the darkest by far, the extraordinary The Naked Spur included. All the hallmarks of his later classics are there, but without any commercial compromise. In most of Mann's westerns, the hero is redeemed kicking and screaming in spite of himself. In Devil's Doorway alone it is not the hero who is in need of redemption, but the country, an idea he wouldn't return to until 1964's The Fall of the Roman Empire. You know that there is no way this one is going to have a happy ending: against all expectations for major studio fare of its day, it doesn't.It constantly goes against the grain, even the casting playing against expectations, with a monumentally miscast Robert Taylor, replete with none-too-convincing make-up as the Native American hero, gradually managing to shrug off his matinee idol image to turn in his best screen performance - headstrong, angry and surprisingly impassioned - in a role that must have been surprisingly relevant when the film was shot only four years after the end of WW2. Like many GIs returning from the war (be it WW2 or Korea), his character has spent the past few years fighting for the American dream in the Civil War only to find out that he's not eligible, in his case by virtue of his color. The notion of a truly United States that he fought for, a utopia where people "didn't die for nothing," proves a lie. The sense of post-war disillusionment that fuelled the film noir genre constantly drives both the story and the remarkable visual style of the film in ways almost unique in the genre.In a curious but highly effective inversion of traditional lighting techniques, in the night scenes the foregrounds and interiors are darkly lit, rendering the players silhouettes, while the valley that dominates the action is clearly visible. The film noir connections go beyond John Alton's lighting. Like the traditional noir hero, Taylor finds that nothing he does can avert the deepening nightmare that ultimately destroys him. He tries to act within the law, but finds himself frustrated by it at every turn. Despite fighting for the United States and earning a Congressional Medal, he finds that in the eyes of the law he is not even an American citizen. It is illegal for him to homestead his own land. It is illegal for him to buy it back from homesteaders. Even a petition from the few sympathetic townspeople is dismissed out of hand.Yet surprisingly, instead of reducing his plight to black and white moral issues, Guy Trosper's screenplay deals in shades of grey. The sheep men who persecute him are not the caricatures you might expect - their problems are just as pressing as his. Nor is the racial prejudice overdone or driven home with sledgehammer pontificating: the hate is there, so ingrained that it doesn't need to be emphasised. Even Louis Calhern's tormenter-in-chief regards hating `redskins' as such a natural thing that he never descends into overstated melodramatic villainy, the actor responding with a skilled performance that makes him all the more immoveable and unyielding for being the human incarnation of the way things have always been. Mann underplays his `comeuppance,' placing it well before the film's finale (remarkably similar to the pitched battle at the end of Cimino's `Heaven's Gate) and its tragic conclusion. It is inevitable, unsatisfying and ultimately resolves nothing. Like everything else Lance does on both sides of the law, it is totally futile. From the moment he returns, he has no control over his fate.There is no doubt that the film would never have been made without the influence of Dore Schary, the liberal at King Louis' court at MGM, but with this and his later, bitterly disillusioned Men in War, it is surprising that Mann did not come under the kind of unwelcome scrutiny by the HUAC enjoyed by many of his contemporaries. Perhaps it was because even when it came out it was so under the radar that, in many ways, it missed the boat. A nervous MGM shelved it until the later, and lighter Broken Arrow was released and took all the critical and box-office laurels and gave audiences a more hopeful ending than the still shockingly stark and bitter one Mann delivers in a remarkably uncompromising film that was decades ahead of its time. Incredibly powerful, it deserves to be so much better known.
summary: The darkest and most powerful of Anthony Mann's Westerns
